bb

the blind spot

Jan 19, 2019

I enjoyed this essay on aeon quite a lot. It’s one of those pieces of writing where you have the feeling that it does not really communicate something new, yet it does strike you again. It evokes a lot of those loose thoughts you have while cycling or when reading something, but you never take the time to write a similar essay yourself. That said, the article discusses the limits of science, and more importantly, urges us, scientists, to abandon the highly problematic objectivist and pysicalist stances that are presumably so common among practicing scientists, and to live and eradiate a new science which takes into account the ‘subject’ of western philosophy. It might be good read to come back to once in a while, to stimulate new thoughts.

But, apart from the main message of the essay, it did bring something new to my awareness, namely ‘Quantum Bayesianism’ (QBism) and ‘participatory realism’. From the looks of it, it’s a highly interesting subject very related to the Jaynesian account of probability which I am kind of liking. Quantum theory forces scientist into some account of the subject, and it seems that this QBism goes quite far in which roles it gives to the subject. In a word, QBists argue that their interpretation of Quantum mechanics leads to a ‘participatory realism’ (and not an anti-realism as some critcis argued), where “reality consists of more than can be captured by any putative third-person account of it”, a very tempting and sexy thing to say indeed.

Some thoughts on it:

  • At first sight it seems however to do a great deal of mixing up physical causility with logical necessity, and all those other things Jaynes seems to spend a lot of effort to make clear we shouldn’t do.
  • The wikipedia page is quite good and has a lot of interesting references to arXiv papers. Like this one
  • Quanta interview with one of the founders (Fuchs)
  • An apparently legendary document by this same Fuchs. It is mainly a collection of e-mails written to colleagues. There is also a second volume apparently. Fuchs seems a very interesting thinker.
  • Turns out they align more with deFinetti than with Jaynes.
φ   science
